title: 莊子
source: Chinese Text Project (ctext.org) - James Legge translation

passages.zh: 馬，蹄可以踐霜雪，毛可以禦風寒，齕草飲水，翹足而陸。
passages.en: Horses can with their hoofs tread on the hoarfrost and snow, and with their hair withstand the wind and cold; they feed on the grass and drink water; they prance with their legs and leap:

passages.zh: 此馬之真性也。
passages.en: this is the true nature of horses.

passages.zh: 雖有義臺、路寢，無所用之。
passages.en: Though there were made for them grand towers and large dormitories, they would prefer not to use them.

passages.zh: 及至伯樂，曰：「我善治馬。」
passages.en: But when Bo-le (arose and) said, 'I know well how to manage horses,'

passages.zh: 燒之剔之，刻之雒之，連之以羈馽，編之以皁棧，馬之死者十二三矣；
passages.en: (men proceeded) to singe and mark them, to clip their hair, to pare their hoofs, to halter their heads, to bridle them and hobble them, and to confine them in stables and corrals. (When subjected to this treatment), two or three in every ten of them died.

passages.zh: 飢之渴之，馳之驟之，整之齊之，前有橛飾之患，而後有鞭筴之威，而馬之死者已過半矣。
passages.en: (Men proceeded further) to subject them to hunger and thirst, to gallop them and race them, and to make them go together in regular order. In front were the evils of the bit and ornamented breastbands, and behind were the terrors of the whip and switch. (When so treated), more than half of them died.

passages.zh: 陶者曰：「我善治埴，圓者中規，方者中矩。」
passages.en: The (first) potter said, 'I know well how to deal with clay;' and (men proceeded) to mould it into circles as exact as if made by the compass, and into squares as exact as if formed by the measuring square.

passages.zh: 匠人曰：「我善治木，曲者中鉤，直者應繩。」
passages.en: The (first) carpenter said, 'I know well how to deal with wood;' and (men proceeded) to make it bent as if by the application of the hook, and straight as if by the application of the plumb-line.

passages.zh: 夫埴、木之性，豈欲中規矩鉤繩哉？
passages.en: But is it the nature of clay and wood to require the application of the compass and square, of the hook and line?

passages.zh: 然且世世稱之曰：「伯樂善治馬，而陶、匠善治埴木。」
passages.en: And yet age after age men have praised Bo-le, saying, 'He knew well how to manage horses,' and also the (first) potter and carpenter, saying, 'They knew well how to deal with clay and wood.'

passages.zh: 此亦治天下者之過也。
passages.en: This is just the error committed by the governors of the world.

passages.zh: 吾意善治天下者不然。
passages.en: According to my idea, those who knew well to govern mankind would not act so.

passages.zh: 彼民有常性，織而衣，耕而食，是謂同德；
passages.en: The people had their regular and constant nature: they wove and made themselves clothes; they tilled the ground and got food. This was their common faculty.

passages.zh: 一而不黨，命曰天放。
passages.en: They were all one in this, and did not form themselves into separate classes; so were they constituted and left to their natural tendencies.

passages.zh: 故至德之世，其行填填，其視顛顛。
passages.en: Therefore in the age of perfect virtue men walked along with slow and grave step, and with their looks steadily directed forwards.

passages.zh: 當是時也，山無蹊隧，澤無舟梁；
passages.en: At that time, on the hills there were no foot-paths, nor excavated passages; on the lakes there were no boats nor dams;

passages.zh: 萬物群生，連屬其鄉；
passages.en: all creatures lived in companies; and the places of their settlement were made close to one another.

passages.zh: 禽獸成群，草木遂長。
passages.en: Birds and beasts multiplied to flocks and herds; the grass and trees grew luxuriant and long.

passages.zh: 是故禽獸可係羈而遊，烏鵲之巢可攀援而闚。
passages.en: In this condition the birds and beasts might be led about without feeling the constraint; the nest of the magpie might be climbed to, and peeped into.

passages.zh: 夫至德之世，同與禽獸居，族與萬物並，惡乎知君子小人哉！
passages.en: Yes, in the age of perfect virtue, men lived in common with birds and beasts, and were on terms of equality with all creatures, as forming one family - how could they know among themselves the distinctions of superior men and small men?

passages.zh: 同乎無知，其德不離；
passages.en: Equally without knowledge, they did not leave (the path of) their natural virtue;

passages.zh: 同乎無欲，是謂素樸。
passages.en: equally free from desires, they were in the state of pure simplicity.

passages.zh: 素樸而民性得矣。
passages.en: In that state of pure simplicity, the nature of the people was what it ought to be.

passages.zh: 及至聖人，蹩躠為仁，踶跂為義，而天下始疑矣；
passages.en: But when the sagely men appeared, limping and wheeling about in (the exercise of) benevolence, pressing along and standing on tiptoe in the doing of righteousness, then men universally began to be perplexed.

passages.zh: 澶漫為樂，摘僻為禮，而天下始分矣。
passages.en: (Those sages also) went to excess in their performances of music, and in their gesticulations in the practice of ceremonies, and then men began to be separated from one another.

passages.zh: 故純樸不殘，孰為犧尊！
passages.en: If the raw materials had not been cut and hacked, who could have made a sacrificial vase from them?

passages.zh: 白玉不毀，孰為珪璋！
passages.en: If the natural jade had not been broken and injured, who could have made the handles for the libation-cups from it?

passages.zh: 道德不廢，安取仁義！
passages.en: If the attributes of the Dao had not been disallowed, how should they have preferred benevolence and righteousness?

passages.zh: 性情不離，安用禮樂！
passages.en: If the instincts of the nature had not been departed from, how should ceremonies and music have come into use?

passages.zh: 五色不亂，孰為文采！
passages.en: If the five colours had not been confused, how should the ornamental figures have been formed?

passages.zh: 五聲不亂，孰應六律！
passages.en: If the five notes had not been confused, how should they have supplemented them by the musical accords?

passages.zh: 夫殘樸以為器，工匠之罪也；
passages.en: The cutting and hacking of the raw materials to form vessels was the crime of the skilful workman;

passages.zh: 毀道德以為仁義，聖人之過也。
passages.en: the injury done to the characteristics of the Dao in order to the practice of benevolence and righteousness was the error of the sagely men.

passages.zh: 夫馬，陸居則食草飲水，喜則交頸相靡，怒則分背相踶。
passages.en: Horses, when living in the open country, eat the grass, and drink water; when pleased, they intertwine their necks and rub one another; when enraged, they turn back to back and kick one another -

passages.zh: 馬知已此矣。
passages.en: this is all that they know to do.

passages.zh: 夫加之以衡扼，齊之以月題，而馬知介倪、闉扼、鷙曼、詭銜、竊轡。
passages.en: But if we put the yoke on their necks, with the moonlike frontlet displayed on all their foreheads, then they know to look slily askance, to curve their necks, to rush viciously, trying to get the bit out of their mouths, and to filch the reins (from their driver);

passages.zh: 故馬之知而態至盜者，伯樂之罪也。
passages.en: this knowledge of the horse and its ability thus to act the part of a thief is the crime of Bo-le.

passages.zh: 夫赫胥氏之時，民居不知所為，行不知所之，含哺而熙，鼓腹而遊，民能以此矣。
passages.en: In the time of (the Di) He-xu, the people occupied their dwellings without knowing what they were doing, and walked out without knowing where they were going. They filled their mouths with food and were glad; they slapped their stomachs to express their satisfaction. This was all the ability which they possessed.

passages.zh: 及至聖人，屈折禮樂以匡天下之形，縣跂仁義以慰天下之心，而民乃始踶跂好知，爭歸於利，不可止也。
passages.en: But when the sagely men appeared, with their bendings and stoppings in ceremonies and music to adjust the persons of all, and hanging up their benevolence and righteousness to excite the endeavours of all to reach them, in order to comfort their minds, then the people began to stump and limp about in their love of knowledge, and strove with one another in their pursuit of gain, so that there was no stopping them:

passages.zh: 此亦聖人之過也。
passages.en: this was the error of those sagely men.
